title: Not every new champion needs to have some complex kit
body:
Not every new champion needs to have 36 dashes, 9 knockups, 12 ability interactions, a new CC effect added into the game, a recastable ability (boy does riot love those) and weird-ass hitboxes.

Cant we just get a simple kit like lux or ashe or karma?

For example:

Passive: Every third ability does x more damage or is x% more effective
Q: Deal damage in a line
W: Slow a target for 2 seconds
E: You deal X% more damage for 3 seconds
R: Deal damage in a cone and silence people

Its so simple. Not everyone needs flashy LC$ kits.

Funny thing about that, their kits are not complex, but they also have minimal interaction.

Mundo: Only his Q is interactive, and even then it's a fast moving projectile with rather low range, making it less about you and more about the Mundo. The only time Mundo is considered viable is when his ultimate is viable, which has no enemy interaction whatsoever except for applying grevious wounds on him.

Tryndamere: No interactivity from his enemies, besides maybe moving away from where he's spinning (even then the spin can be cast point blank at no cast animation.) His ultimate doesn't even allow for you to crowd control him; he can use it at any time he chooses.

Singed: Only his W, and even then I wouldn't consider that interactive. It's a slow field that stops you from using any escapes, then he just runs at you with a point and click flip, as well as a stat stick bonus on his ultimate.

Master Yi: Point and click and auto attacks, as well as instant start to cast on every ability he has (you don't have a full second to interrupt his alpha.) 

Wukong: Either you're in range of him and he can hit you, or you're not. No in between with his kit being entirely based around that (point and click as well as damage around him.)

Teemo: Point and click on everything but his ultimate, which you will either step on and take a ton of damage, or just buy something like an oracle lens and promptly ignore.

Garen: Nothing to dodge. Q is an auto modifier, W is just "press for defense" (in the simplest terms), his E is deal damage around him, and his ultimate is a 400 range point and click spell that also executes.

This is actually mostly a problem with melee champions in general; most of the times their kits are just "are you in range?" rather than anything else.

I'm also surprised that you didn't mention {{champion:1}} . Her passive is a stun on every 4th ability, her Q is point and click, her W is cone damage with little to no animation, her E is instant, and her ultimate is a near instant AOE attack that summons a pet.

On another note, it's not just easy champions that have this kind of issue. {{champion:238}} will avoid using his Q to kill you if he can, relying on artificial burst damage like {{item:3147}} whenever possible (ult > E > auto > blink back to shadow, if that's enough to kill you.)

{{champion:142}} has, or had, an issue where she wasn't using her E to kill people, relying on her W's movement speed, damage, and Q/passive to kill people without putting them to sleep. 

People will always maximize player input to game output, no matter what the developers had in mind.

Personally, I do enjoy simple champions, playing champions such as Ryze, Garen, and Ashe. 

However the problem is, all simple mechanics have already been taken. It would simply take abilities that old champions already have and offer nothing new in return. With so many champions in the game, there would be no reason for their existence, because they will simply be a copy of previous champs. Your example is the very example of a stat check champion, not very good design.

At this point, newer champions must have newer mechanics, which often turn out to be very flashy (which I'm not too fond of). I think there is an excess of champions, but at the same time, only so few get picked in favor for meta ones. Pretty much quality over quantity. I would rather they refine outdated champions through reworks (Warwick is a good example), than release new champions. That way we can retain simple kits from older champions, updated to better fit the new state of the game.

Will they release champions indefinitely? At some number of champions, there will be too many to balance. With each addition, each champion becomes a smaller part of the pool, reuse more the same abilities as other champions, and thus become less unique in general. An oversaturation of champions.

Riot's official statement on the matter:
https://nexus.leagueoflegends.com/en-pl/2018/06/ask-riot-skins-and-champions/
___
___

#Q
_Some of my favorite champs in the past have been the ones with simple, more straightforward kits and gameplay: old cho’gath, old swain, old taric. Are there any plans to make new champions with simple and easy playstyles?_
___
___
#A
_Simple, straightforward champs have a lot of pros and cons, but overall we agree that they are an important and fun part of the LoL roster. The big benefit is that it opens up a more decision-based and less input-mechanics-based playstyle that’s really appealing to some types of players (especially new ones). A cost and common drawback is that they’re often much more powerful in low elo play, so when balanced, they end up being a non-viable option in higher levels of play. Simple champions can also devolve much more quickly into “stat check” gameplay when they’re snowballed ahead or behind because they don’t have enough tools to outplay their opponents._

_To answer your original question—**we will likely not be adding a lot more of the “old Taric” style of champions to the game** because we think that the amount we have right now is serving that niche pretty well. In the cases of VGUs, we are trying to keep the simple champs simple when we can. I think Warwick was a good example of this, where we made a lot of good changes to his kit without pushing it into a high mechanics space._

___

So don't expect new champions to have simple kits.

Karma's easy to play though.

As a shield bot maybe. Try playing her as a 1v5 champ. Who pulls in over 30k heals a game because she plays roulette with her health the entire game. 1 man blocks 3 lanes from collapsing to both minions and champs pushing.....

Mechanically she's not hard. But she has a high skill cap. And then there's a layer of logistical skill on top of that most other champs don't have because of her R choices.
It is basic but has options, and something more important not a ton of dashes. Ironically support champions like her and Lulu might be some of the better build "basic" champs in the game right now.

Which is why they are historically balance nightmares. Champions like Lulu shouldn't be allowed to be "good" because the amount of brainpower it takes to absolutely counter any sort of aggression is laughable at best. Lulu has ONE skillshot in her entire kit meaning you can only actually play around ONE ability. If you dive on Lulu and she happens to hover over you and hit W or hits R on herself you are going to die because she happened to click a few buttons. Back when Lulu+Kog was INCREDIBLY strong (5.0 as kog with ardent) you could honestly play Lulu and hardly look at the screen and just put your cursor over kog's portrait in the bottom right and spam W and E (they had almost 100% uptime anyway and you had infinite mana regen from support items).

Also, another thing is generalist champions also shouldn't be able to outclass dedicated specialists in their own field. Lulu who is much more aggressive than the likes of Janna (who is a problem in her own right) shouldn't be able to peel as well as her, yet against 1-2 divers can easily get the job done just as well since W and R are both huge "no" buttons. Her shield which can double as damage shouldn't be remotely as strong as Janna's yet time and time again has been on the same playing field while still providing damage at the same time (that also doesn't get removed when the shield drops).

Enchanter supports until the class gets reworked just doesn't ever feel "fair" to play against if they are good. Like the fact that when strong Karma could easily outshield most of a teamfight mage's damage by using R+E and still having a Locket available isn't fun. We can lure the entire enemy team into a choke where I land a bullseye 5 man Ziggs ult and Karma hitting R+E and negating over half of the total damage on a MUCH shorter cooldown where you just have to kind of pay attention isn't interactive. It isn't NEARLY as bad now that you can't just pre-emptively shield everything THAT easily, but it will still be annoying since the only way to "play around" massive shields from supports it seems is to play at 5 AM and hope that Lulu starts dozing off a little bit in the game.

To be fair Lulu and Karma takes way more skill then someone like Janna to play. If they miss their one skill-shot or use skills the wrong way they become way less effective. I play a ton of assassins and to be honest I know if I face either of them they are dangerous, and I am okay with that. 

Lulu cant 1 shot me, nor can she kill a tank. All she can do is make it so I cant do my job properly, but do you know who is way worst to play vs? Garen, Tryndamere, Darius or Tahm Kench. They actually just sit there doing nothing well you die which is a true joke.  Some enchanters are braindead and easy to play, but Lulu and karma are way more enjoyable to play vs then Janna who stops everyone and everything in their tracks, or brand or Zyra who can actually solo carry games.

I've seen a few comments here that conflate complexity with uniqueness or fairness, but I feel those comments also readily ignore the stream of recent designs we've had, many of which have had a ton of overlap with previous kits in spite of their complexity, and many of which have also been unhealthy, often to a far worse degree than older champions such as Garen or Annie. When every new kit is given so much stuff that they end up doing much of the same, e.g. AoE damage, AoE CC (especially displacement), and mobility, the end result isn't particularly diverse. Similarly, when a kit tries to be complex just for the sake of being complex, rather than because that complexity brings greater health, the product is a champion that is more difficult to balance or fix in the longer term, as they have many more moving parts to take into account. Complexity can and does bring opportunities for more depth, but only if used properly and sparingly. Currently, a lot of kits are pretty gratuitously complex, and that mechanical overload has often been directly responsible for their downfall.

I think it's also worth bringing in a little more perspective on this matter: League isn't the only MOBA on the market, and there are plenty of other games that manage to have a large roster of characters, characters that stand out from each other while often retaining simple, intuitive kits. HotS is probably the best example of this, but Dota 2 also has a whole bunch of heroes that are extremely simple, yet full of depth (it also has some _really_ complex ones too, though their complexity has a purpose). Smite has the issue of having a lot of samey effects (especially dashes), but still has a lot of distinct kits whose abilities can each usually be described in a couple of sentences. This is just within the MOBA genre, and there are plenty more games beyond that which demonstrate how to extract a ton of depth from a minimal amount of complexity. We could all benefit from looking at these other games, and thereby realizing that the complexity we've experienced in League is not a necessity, but an ongoing developer choice that hasn't panned out all that well.
